version: '3.8'

services:
  # Main application service
  app:
    build:
      context: ../..
      dockerfile: .skogai/docker/Dockerfile
      target: runtime
    container_name: partstown-app
    environment:
      - ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT=Development
      - ConnectionStrings__DefaultConnection=Server=sqlserver;Database=PartsTown;User Id=sa;Password=YourStrong@Passw0rd;TrustServerCertificate=True
      - MONO_THREADS_PER_CPU=2000
      - MONO_GC_PARAMS=nursery-size=64m
    ports:
      - "8080:80"
      - "8443:443"
    volumes:
      # Mount source code for development (hot reload)
      - ../../PartsTown:/app/PartsTown:ro
      - ../../PartsTown.Tests:/app/PartsTown.Tests:ro
      # Mount scripts
      - ../../.skogai/scripts:/app/scripts:ro
      # Separate volume for packages to persist between rebuilds
      - nuget-packages:/app/packages
    depends_on:
      - sqlserver
    networks:
      - partstown-network
    command: ["run"]

  # SQL Server for database operations
  sqlserver:
    image: mcr.microsoft.com/mssql/server:2019-latest
    container_name: partstown-sqlserver
    environment:
      - ACCEPT_EULA=Y
      - SA_PASSWORD=YourStrong@Passw0rd
      - MSSQL_PID=Express
      - MSSQL_AGENT_ENABLED=true
    ports:
      - "1433:1433"
    volumes:
      - sqlserver-data:/var/opt/mssql
      # Mount any SQL scripts for initialization
      - ../../.skogai/docker/sql-init:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d:ro
    networks:
      - partstown-network
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "/opt/mssql-tools/bin/sqlcmd -S localhost -U sa -P YourStrong@Passw0rd -Q 'SELECT 1' || exit 1"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5
      start_period: 30s

  # Test runner service
  test:
    build:
      context: ../..
      dockerfile: .skogai/docker/Dockerfile
      target: runtime
    container_name: partstown-tests
    environment:
      - ConnectionStrings__TestConnection=Server=sqlserver;Database=PartsTownTest;User Id=sa;Password=YourStrong@Passw0rd;TrustServerCertificate=True
      - TEST_ENVIRONMENT=Docker
    volumes:
      # Mount test results directory
      - ../../TestResults:/app/TestResults
      # Mount source for testing
      - ../../PartsTown:/app/PartsTown:ro
      - ../../PartsTown.Tests:/app/PartsTown.Tests:ro
      # Scripts
      - ../../.skogai/scripts:/app/scripts:ro
      # Packages
      - nuget-packages:/app/packages
    depends_on:
      sqlserver:
        condition: service_healthy
    networks:
      - partstown-network
    command: ["test"]

  # Development tools container (optional)
  devtools:
    build:
      context: ../..
      dockerfile: .skogai/docker/Dockerfile
      target: build
    container_name: partstown-devtools
    environment:
      - TERM=xterm-256color
    volumes:
      # Mount entire source for development
      - ../..:/workspace
      # Share packages
      - nuget-packages:/workspace/packages
      # Mount docker socket for container management
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
    networks:
      - partstown-network
    stdin_open: true
    tty: true
    command: ["/bin/bash"]

networks:
  partstown-network:
    driver: bridge

volumes:
  sqlserver-data:
    driver: local
  nuget-packages:
    driver: local

file.content:
# Multi-stage Dockerfile for PartsTown .NET Framework 4.8 application

# Stage 1: Build environment
FROM mono:latest AS build

# Fix EOL Debian Buster repositories to use archive
RUN sed -i 's|http://deb.debian.org/debian|http://archive.debian.org/debian|g' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && sed -i 's|http://security.debian.org/debian-security|http://archive.debian.org/debian-security|g' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && sed -i '/buster-updates/d' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && echo 'Acquire::Check-Valid-Until "false";' > /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/99no-check-valid-until

# Install packages
RUN apt-get update \
    && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
    # VB.NET support for Microsoft.VisualBasic
    mono-vbnc \
    # Graphics/Drawing support for PresentationCore and System.Drawing
    libgdiplus \
    libc6-dev \
    # SSL/TLS certificates for Azure and API calls
    ca-certificates \
    # Build essentials
    wget \
    unzip \
    git \
    # SQL Server client tools
    curl \
    apt-transport-https \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Install NuGet
RUN wget -q https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest/nuget.exe -O /usr/local/bin/nuget.exe

# Create NuGet wrapper script
RUN echo '#!/bin/bash\nmono /usr/local/bin/nuget.exe "$@"' > /usr/local/bin/nuget \
    && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/nuget

# Set working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy solution and project files first (for better layer caching)
COPY *.sln ./
COPY PartsTown/*.csproj ./PartsTown/
COPY PartsTown/*.config ./PartsTown/
COPY PartsTown.Tests/*.csproj ./PartsTown.Tests/

# Copy NuGet.config if it exists
COPY NuGet.config* ./

# Restore NuGet packages
RUN nuget restore PartsTown.sln -NonInteractive

# Copy source code
COPY . .

# Restore again after copying all files (for PackageReferences in test project)
RUN dotnet restore PartsTown.Tests/PartsTown.Tests.csproj || true

# Build the solution (allow failures for now)
RUN msbuild PartsTown.sln /p:Configuration=Development /p:Platform="Any CPU" /p:DebugType=Full || \
    msbuild PartsTown/PartsTown.csproj /p:Configuration=Development /p:Platform="Any CPU"

# Stage 2: Runtime and Test environment
FROM mono:latest AS runtime

# Fix EOL Debian Buster repositories to use archive
RUN sed -i 's|http://deb.debian.org/debian|http://archive.debian.org/debian|g' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && sed -i 's|http://security.debian.org/debian-security|http://archive.debian.org/debian-security|g' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && sed -i '/buster-updates/d' /etc/apt/sources.list \
    && echo 'Acquire::Check-Valid-Until "false";' > /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/99no-check-valid-until

# Install runtime dependencies
RUN apt-get update \
    && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
    # VB.NET runtime
    mono-vbnc \
    # Graphics support
    libgdiplus \
    # SSL/TLS certificates
    ca-certificates \
    # Utilities for debugging and tools
    curl \
    wget \
    unzip \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Install xUnit console runner for tests
RUN mkdir -p /tools/xunit && \
    wget -q https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/xunit.runner.console/2.9.3 -O /tmp/xunit.zip && \
    unzip -q /tmp/xunit.zip -d /tools/xunit && \
    rm /tmp/xunit.zip

WORKDIR /app

# Copy build output from build stage
COPY --from=build /app/PartsTown/bin ./PartsTown/bin
COPY --from=build /app/PartsTown.Tests/bin ./PartsTown.Tests/bin
COPY --from=build /app/packages ./packages

# Copy configuration files
COPY --from=build /app/PartsTown/Web.config ./PartsTown/
COPY --from=build /app/PartsTown/Web.*.config ./PartsTown/

# Create entrypoint script directly (avoiding COPY issues)
RUN cat > /usr/local/bin/docker-entrypoint.sh << 'EOF' && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-entrypoint.sh
#!/bin/bash
set -e

wait_for_sqlserver() {
    echo "Waiting for SQL Server..."
    for i in {1..30}; do
        if timeout 1 bash -c "cat < /dev/null > /dev/tcp/sqlserver/1433" 2>/dev/null; then
            echo "SQL Server is ready!"
            return 0
        fi
        echo "Attempt $i/30: SQL Server not ready yet..."
        sleep 2
    done
    echo "SQL Server did not become ready in time"
    return 1
}

case "$1" in
    run|start|server)
        echo "Starting PartsTown application..."
        wait_for_sqlserver || true
        cd /app/PartsTown
        xsp4 --port 80 --nonstop
        ;;
    test)
        echo "Running tests..."
        wait_for_sqlserver || true
        mono /tools/xunit/tools/net48/xunit.console.exe \
            /app/PartsTown.Tests/bin/Debug/net48/PartsTown.Tests.dll \
            -xml /app/TestResults/results.xml || true
        ;;
    build)
        echo "Building solution..."
        cd /app
        msbuild PartsTown.sln /p:Configuration=Development
        ;;
    shell|bash)
        exec /bin/bash
        ;;
    *)
        echo "Usage: {run|test|build|shell}"
        exit 1
        ;;
esac
EOF

# Expose port for the application
EXPOSE 80
EXPOSE 443

# Set environment variables
ENV MONO_THREADS_PER_CPU=2000
ENV MONO_GC_PARAMS=nursery-size=64m

# Default entrypoint
ENTRYPOINT ["docker-entrypoint.sh"]
CMD ["run"]

## Docker Build Issues Analysis & Proposed Fixes

### Issues Found:
1. **Missing NuGet package**: `Lucene.Net 4.8.0-beta00017` not found during test project build
2. **Build configuration mismatch**: The Dockerfile tries to build with `Configuration=Development` but project lacks proper OutputPath for this config
3. **Mixed build tools**: Dockerfile attempts to use both `dotnet` (line 57) and `msbuild` (line 60) but `dotnet` isn't installed in the mono image

### Proposed Changes:

#### 1. Fix Dockerfile build commands:
- Remove the `dotnet restore` command (line 57) since dotnet SDK isn't available in mono image
- Ensure NuGet restore includes test packages properly
- Fix the build configuration to use existing Debug configuration

#### 2. Update docker-compose.yml:
- Remove deprecated `version` field (line 1)
- Fix the devtools service target to match actual Dockerfile stage name

#### 3. Improve docker-up script:
- Add error handling
- Check if docker-compose file exists before running
- Add option to rebuild images

### Specific File Changes:

**`.skogai/docker/Dockerfile`:**
- Line 57: Remove the dotnet restore line entirely
- Line 60-61: Change build configuration from "Development" to "Debug" (which exists in csproj)
- Add explicit NuGet restore for test project

**`.skogai/docker/docker-compose.yml`:**
- Line 1: Remove the `version: '3.8'` line
- Consider using docker compose v2 commands

**`.skogai/scripts/docker-up`:**
- Add validation and error handling
- Support rebuild flag
- Use docker compose v2 syntax

content.text:
## The Problem:

You're absolutely right! This is a **.NET Framework 4.8** application that's trying to run on Linux with Mono, which is causing issues because:

1. **PresentationCore** and other WPF/Windows-specific assemblies don't work on Mono
2. **IIS-specific configurations** in the project
3. **Missing Windows-specific dependencies**
4. The build error shows it can't resolve Windows-specific assemblies

## Recommended Solution:

For .NET Framework 4.8 applications, you should use **Windows containers** with one of these base images:

```dockerfile
# Option 1: Full .NET Framework with IIS (for web apps)
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/aspnet:4.8-windowsservercore-ltsc2022

# Option 2: SDK for building
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/sdk:4.8-windowsservercore-ltsc2022

# Option 3: Lighter Windows Server Core
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/runtime:4.8-windowsservercore-ltsc2022
```

## Why Windows Containers?

- .NET Framework 4.8 is Windows-only
- Full compatibility with all Windows APIs
- IIS support built-in
- No compatibility layer issues
- All NuGet packages will work as expected

## Important Note:

**Windows containers require**:
- Windows host (Windows 10/11 Pro or Server) OR
- Linux host with Windows container support (experimental)
- Docker Desktop switched to Windows containers mode

Would you like me to create a proper Windows-based Dockerfile for your .NET Framework 4.8 application?

## Windows Container Solution for .NET Framework 4.8 Application

### Proposed Changes:

#### 1. **New Windows-based Dockerfile** (`.skogai/docker/Dockerfile`)
Replace the Linux/Mono Dockerfile with a Windows container setup:

**Build stage:**
- Base: `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/sdk:4.8-windowsservercore-ltsc2022`
- Use MSBuild and NuGet for Windows
- Proper .NET Framework build tools

**Runtime stage:**
- Base: `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/aspnet:4.8-windowsservercore-ltsc2022`
- IIS with ASP.NET pre-configured
- Full .NET Framework 4.8 runtime

#### 2. **Updated docker-compose.yml**
- Remove deprecated `version` field
- Use Windows-compatible SQL Server image
- Adjust volume mounts for Windows paths
- Configure IIS application pool settings

#### 3. **Enhanced docker-up script**
- Add Docker mode check (Windows vs Linux containers)
- Add rebuild options
- Better error handling
- Support for Windows-specific networking

### Key Improvements:
- **Full Windows compatibility** - No more Mono/Linux compatibility issues
- **Native IIS hosting** - Proper ASP.NET hosting environment
- **All NuGet packages work** - Including PresentationCore, WPF, etc.
- **Better performance** - Native Windows execution
- **Proper debugging** - Full PDB support

### File Structure (maintaining existing layout):
```
.skogai/
├── docker/
│   ├── Dockerfile          # Windows-based container
│   ├── docker-compose.yml  # Updated for Windows
│   └── sql-init/          # SQL initialization scripts
└── scripts/
    └── docker-up           # Enhanced startup script
```

### Requirements:
- Docker Desktop with Windows containers mode enabled
- Windows 10/11 Pro or Windows Server host
- At least 8GB RAM allocated to Docker

Ready to implement these Windows container configurations?

content.text:
## Options for Running .NET Framework 4.8 on Linux:

### 1. **Fix the Mono Approach** (Current attempt - can work with modifications)
The current Dockerfile uses Mono, which CAN work but needs fixes:
- **Remove Windows-specific dependencies** (PresentationCore, WPF)
- **Fix build configuration** (use Debug instead of Development)
- **Use proper Mono-compatible web server** (XSP4 or nginx+fastcgi-mono-server4)

### 2. **Wine + .NET Framework** (Complex but possible)
Run Windows .NET Framework inside Wine on Linux:
```dockerfile
FROM ubuntu:22.04
# Install Wine, winetricks, .NET Framework 4.8
# Run IIS Express or self-hosted
```

### 3. **Migration to .NET 6/7/8** (Best long-term solution)
Convert to cross-platform .NET:
- Full Linux compatibility
- Better performance
- Modern tooling
- But requires code changes

### 4. **Windows Containers on Linux** (Experimental)
- Using LCOW (Linux Containers on Windows) in reverse
- Very experimental and limited support

## Fixing Current Mono Approach

Looking at the errors, the main issues are:
1. **Missing Lucene.Net package** - Need proper restore
2. **Wrong build configuration** - Use "Debug" not "Development"
3. **PresentationCore reference** - This is WPF/Windows-only, needs removal or conditional compilation

## Yes, we CAN run this on Linux! Here's how:

### The Mono approach can work with these fixes:

1. **PresentationCore** is only referenced but might not be actively used (it's a WPF component). We can:
   - Remove it if unused
   - Or stub it out for Linux

2. **Fix the immediate build issues:**
   - Change `Development` to `Debug` configuration
   - Remove the `dotnet restore` line (line 57)
   - Fix NuGet package restoration

3. **Use proper Mono web hosting:**
   - XSP4 (development server) 
   - Or nginx + fastcgi-mono-server4 (production)

## Linux-Compatible Solution with Mono (Fixed)

### Proposed Changes to Run on Linux:

#### 1. **Fix Dockerfile** (`.skogai/docker/Dockerfile`)

**Immediate fixes:**
- Line 57: Remove `dotnet restore` command (dotnet SDK not available in mono image)
- Line 60-61: Change configuration from "Development" to "Debug" 
- Add conditional compilation to handle PresentationCore

**Updated build commands:**
```dockerfile
# Remove line 57 entirely
# Replace lines 60-61 with:
RUN msbuild PartsTown.sln /p:Configuration=Debug /p:Platform="Any CPU" /p:DebugType=Full /p:DefineConstants="MONO_BUILD" || \
    msbuild PartsTown/PartsTown.csproj /p:Configuration=Debug /p:Platform="Any CPU" /p:DefineConstants="MONO_BUILD"
```

#### 2. **Update docker-compose.yml**
- Remove `version: '3.8'` line (deprecated)
- Keep Linux-compatible SQL Server image
- Fix build target reference

#### 3. **Handle PresentationCore Reference**
Add conditional compilation in `.csproj`:
```xml
<Reference Include="PresentationCore" Condition="'$(MONO_BUILD)' != 'true'" />
```
Or remove if not actually used in code.

#### 4. **Install Missing Dependencies**
Add to Dockerfile build stage:
```dockerfile
# Install xsp4 for web hosting
RUN apt-get install -y mono-xsp4
```

### Why This Will Work:
- Mono supports most .NET Framework 4.8 APIs
- ASP.NET MVC works well on Mono with XSP4
- SQL Server Linux container is fully compatible
- Removes Windows-only dependencies during Linux build

### Benefits over Windows Containers:
- Runs on any Linux host
- Smaller image size (~500MB vs 5GB+)
- Faster startup times
- No Windows licensing required
- Works on Mac/Linux development machines

Ready to implement these Linux-compatible fixes?
